To the Editor:
Due to all the recent fanfare
concerning the Board ot
Intramural Athletics and its
performance, the Board thought a
statement was in order to dispel
some of the false ideas that seem
to be circulating. Each year, 'the
B.I.A. holds interviews for anyone
interested in applying to the
Board. We definitly strive to obtain
a balanced representation of all
fraternities and independents, but
our selections are limited to those
who apply — in past years, the
majority of the applicants have
come from only two fraternities.
As a general rule, anyone showing
an interest to work for the B.I.A.
from a fraternity not represented
on the Board is accepted with no
arguments. When the applicants
come out of only two fraternities,
the majority of the representatives
selected will be from those
fraternities. Mr. Brown's idea of
manditory participation from all
campus fraternities would result in
people on the Board who _don't
care about the B.I.A. and who
would not be willing to put forth
the time and effort required to
organize a given sport. These sports
would probably end up being run
much less professionally and
efficiently.
Applicants are also selected on
their general knowledge and
background of all sports, and on
any great wealth of knowledge of
one particular sport. Thus, the
members are more than qualified
to vote on rule changes,
interpretations,, and protests of
games that have been played. In
deciding on protests and petitions
to the Board concerning teams or
individuals, decisions are made in
light of the Board's goal which is
to promote maximum
participation and competition in

any particular sport. In certain
special cases, going by the letter of
the law would be directly contrary
to our goals.
Finally, th-e members are
selected to run the individual
sports on the basis of their
knowledge of the sport and their
experience in organizing that sport,
not on a first come first serve basis.
As stated before, some new
members are selected because of an
expansive knowledge of a
particular sport and they are thus
appointed to run that sport. The
participants can be assured that the
members running each sport are
the most qualified people on the
Board to run that sport.
Mr. Brown's arguments and
objections concerning the Board
are given away by his statement in
the beginning of his letter "...to
the best of my knowledge..."
Obviously, his knowledge of the
intramural program is very limited,
and he therefore should not be so
hasty to criticize it. I am sure Mr.
Brown's rejection for membership
to the Board last Spring did not
influence his thinking, especially
when his arguments are reduced to
name calling in his recent letter.
As for Mr. Tillem's and the
Student Council's complaints
about running the Goucher Gallop
on Yom Kippur; all I can say is
that this year's gallop had more
participation than any gallop run
in the last five years. B.I.A.
basketball last Spring was played
on Good Friday. Those of the faith
have the choice of personally
participating in the event or not.
Scheduling of B.I.A. events is very
tight, and we are sorry if anyone
was excluded in this case due to
their observance of the religious
holiday.
Neil Hazard
Pres., Board of Intramural Athletics

To the Editor:
Due to all the recent fanfare
concerning the Board ot
Intramural Athletics and its
performance, the Board thought a
statement was in order to dispel
some of the false ideas that seem
to be circulating. Each year, 'the
B.I.A. holds interviews for anyone
interested in applying to the
Board. We definitly strive to obtain
a balanced representation of all
fraternities and independents, but
our selections are limited to those
who apply — in past years, the
majority of the applicants have
come from only two fraternities.
As a general rule, anyone showing
an interest to work for the B.I.A.
from a fraternity not represented
on the Board is accepted with no
arguments. When the applicants
come out of only two fraternities,
the majority of the representatives
selected will be from those
fraternities. Mr. Brown's idea of
manditory participation from all
campus fraternities would result in
people on the Board who _don't
care about the B.I.A. and who
would not be willing to put forth
the time and effort required to
organize a given sport. These sports
would probably end up being run
much less professionally and
efficiently.
Applicants are also selected on
their general knowledge and
background of all sports, and on
any great wealth of knowledge of
one particular sport. Thus, the
members are more than qualified
to vote on rule changes,
interpretations,, and protests of
games that have been played. In
deciding on protests and petitions
to the Board concerning teams or
individuals, decisions are made in
light of the Board's goal which is
to promote maximum
participation and competition in

any particular sport. In certain
special cases, going by the letter of
the law would be directly contrary
to our goals.
Finally, th-e members are
selected to run the individual
sports on the basis of their
knowledge of the sport and their
experience in organizing that sport,
not on a first come first serve basis.
As stated before, some new
members are selected because of an
expansive knowledge of a
particular sport and they are thus
appointed to run that sport. The
participants can be assured that the
members running each sport are
the most qualified people on the
Board to run that sport.
Mr. Brown's arguments and
objections concerning the Board
are given away by his statement in
the beginning of his letter "...to
the best of my knowledge..."
Obviously, his knowledge of the
intramural program is very limited,
and he therefore should not be so
hasty to criticize it. I am sure Mr.
Brown's rejection for membership
to the Board last Spring did not
influence his thinking, especially
when his arguments are reduced to
name calling in his recent letter.
As for Mr. Tillem's and the
Student Council's complaints
about running the Goucher Gallop
on Yom Kippur; all I can say is
that this year's gallop had more
participation than any gallop run
in the last five years. B.I.A.
basketball last Spring was played
on Good Friday. Those of the faith
have the choice of personally
participating in the event or not.
Scheduling of B.I.A. events is very
tight, and we are sorry if anyone
was excluded in this case due to
their observance of the religious
holiday.
Neil Hazard
Pres., Board of Intramural Athletics

The Johns Hopkins football
team will seek its second
consecutive win tomorrow when

Washington.

schools have ever met in gridiron
competition. Both teams will be
working to even their present 1-2
season records.
Hopkins lost two straight at
the outset of the fall campaign
before rebounding strongly here
last week against the Ursinus
Bears. A carryover from that
effort, coupled with their
continuing improvement during
the week, should give the Blue
Jays firm footing against the
capital squad.
Teachers also suffered twc
setbacks before claiming their
first- win of the year at
Bridgewater College last
Saturday. The school is currently
fielding its third football team
since adding the sport to its
athletic program in 1971.
The Blue Jays settled down to
good solid football Saturday, as
the final 34-13 score indicates.
Senior Jack Thomas was named
the Offensive Player of the Week
for the College Division of the
Middle Atlantic Conference after
turning in a stellar 231 yard total
offense performance against the
Bears. With better support from
his offensive line, the co-captain
was able to gain 94 yards rushing
and throw ten for fifteen.
Thomas' three game totals rank
him at the top of the MAC
Southern Division in passing and
individual total offense.
"We're well prepared for the
game," commented Coach
Dennis Cox, looking forward to
tomorrow's encounter. Without
the assistance of an exchange of
game films, Teachers presents a
bigger uncertainty than most
opponents, but scouting has
shown them to be a big team
with ability.
"They seem to make mistakes,
so we hope to be able to force
them and capitalize on them,"
continued Cox.
The D.C. offense is primarily
concentrated around the talents
of quarterback Tyrone Wilson.
When passing, Wilson often looks
deep for Ronnie Bethea, who has
been a bomb threat for the hosts.
Complementing the ell-owing
game is the job for 20( pound
fullback James Cunningham,
another punishing runner the
Blue Jay defense must contain.
Teachers boasts one of the
largest lines the Blue Jays will
meet all fall, with three men over
250 pounds in the front wall.
Center John Harrell leads the
way at 280, while not one of the
starting five is under 205.
Teachers depends on a pretty
straightforward running game,
although an effective double
reverse was used to good
advantage in their Bridgewater
game.

class of the MAC and the

week and could be on the move

meet challenges.
